For those of you unfamiliar with Mr. Blake's unique oeuvre, suffice it to say you're in for a very special film experience today. The audience goes out of their heads. Edward Ford sits through this nonsense impatiently. He tr to look disapproving as they make a mockery of his late friend.

We're starting off the programme with Blake's own "82@" -- the frankly autobiographical "The She-Male" -- made in 1956 when Blake was at the height of his creative powers Luke is likewise not participating in the audience participation, considering this crowd every bit as creepy the Harry Blake/Edward Ford world they find so hilarious.
a crowning achievement of art povera, a film, like Abel Gance's "Napoleon," in which one man's personal auteurist vision at once refines and revolutionizes the whole concept of cinema  96.

Harold Blake, sitting in a tatty chair in his decrepit apartment at the end of his life, wearing just a dirty pa of trousers and a brassiere, smoking a cigarette, unshave bottle next to him on a side table. The SOUND of the movi marathon continues.

Notice, if you will, in the dialogue scenes of this film the startling use of nonsequitur -- as well as the sense of heightened reality created by the constant repetition of Blake's favorite word "such" -- as in the memorable line, "Such do the sands of time tell us what we have to know of the unknown." We HEAR the audience HOWL with laughter -- as Harold Blak watches a few flies buzzing around him.

Darkened now, the first film showing. Patty Blake, also tanked up, enters carrying a couple of plates of baked beans. She sets them down on the table an starts to take a cracker out of an old box already there. is at this time not quite as eerie-looking as she will become, but still well on the way to her ultimate destiny degradation.

Then in 1958 Blake produced his masterpiece -- "Invaders From Planet Ten!" (audience SCREAMS)  97. A true marriage of idiosyncratic casting and plotting and genuine directorial ineptitude -- the film that most clearly stands today as the highest perfection of Blake's mise en scene. Blake has joined his wife at the table, brought his bottl with him. They start in on the baked beans.

Pay particular attention to the now famous menagerie scene in which there are more mistakes than in any other single sequence in the history of cinema. No series of images in Blake's canon answers more cogently to the total incoherency of his visual style. Patty reaches for the bottle, but Harry pulls it back and yells at her. She tries to grab it again but he keeps it arm's length.

For instance, you'll see the chemist pick up a phone and start talking -- without any preceding ringing or dialing. And when he gets attacked by the giant python, notice how he has to wrap it around himself because Blake couldn't afford an actual working model. Patty finally in fury flings her plate of baked beans at husband. As they drip down his chest and over his bra he comes after her. She gets surprisingly quickly to her fee too, keeping the table in the middle as he tries to get h of her, chasing her around it, has fingers snatching at t air between them. As an extension, he picks up his bottle starts swinging it at her as he chases, whatever drink is left in it spilling as he does -- but Patty's still movin around the table, stumbling from time to time, but still faster than him. finally it occurs to Harry Blake to knoc the damn table aside. He corners his wife, swings the bot at her again, and this time it catches her chin, knocking to the floor.

On the screen, in black-and-white, "flying saucers" swoop down from the skies on strings. Then, in a cut that doesn match at all, a citizen played by Laird Breen points at t sky, though he is clearly in a cheap studio set.

Hubcaps. They're hubcaps. As a "corporal" approaches a "General" on the screen, the audience tenses to speak the dialogue in sync with the actors.

Driving home from the theatre. Edward Ford is quite incen

Tell them that!
Poor old Bela, y'know, he needed some fast dough for his opium habit, so he let Harry shoot some footage on him -- then Harry didn't use it for two years.

And that's another thing -- they said the double was his wife's ophthalmologist -- it was her gynecologist. I knew him -- I met him once over at Harry's. (Luke is laughing) And y'now they said Harry had a little cameo in "The She-Male?"

"Cause there's nothin' on TV. I tell ya, I dread Monday nights. I dread 'em. There ain't nothin' to watch. Not a thing. Nothin' at all.

-- he shit in his pants. And he just took his underwear and threw it off behind a boulder somewhere -- (Luke can't help laughing now)  106. And the smell was so raunchous I got out of the car. I just could not stay in that car. He takes a sip from his glass of orange juice.

Down below in the alley at the large garbage containers, gone-to-seed hippie searches for items of interest.  107.

Edward Ford remains on the left, continuing to talk, Luke feeding him questions, while on the right he goes about h life as usual.
Isn't he on your Big Six? Edward Ford sits in the very same LAUNDROMAT he's been frequenting all these years, watching his underwear going round and round.

(starting to slip into his real voice) Yeah. "The Magnificent Seven."
Did you type him in red for that? Back in his APARTMENT he studies the movie section of the newspaper, making little pencil check marks against possi choices.
